☰ Document Outline

The Svayambhu

Digital Critical Edition and Translation of an Old Javanese Juridical Text

edited by Arlo Griffiths & Timothy Lubin

  • Witnesses
  • Metadata

List of Witnesses

  • L: Leiden, Universiteitsbibliotheek, the Netherlands, Or. 4530: Balinese script on paper, van der Tuuk collection; typed Roman transcript: Leiden BCB portfolio 165
  • K: Kirtya, Singaraja, Bali, Indonesia, 774 (kropak 3) II A/3/774: Balinese script on lontar; typed Roman transcript: HKS 1883 = Leiden Or. 15.027
  • M: Kirtya, Singaraja, Bali, Indonesia, 280 (kropak 3) II A/3/280: Balinese script on lontar; typed Roman transcript: HKS 3046 = Leiden Or. 16.190
  • SvaMSS: The Sanskrit text as implied by the Svayambhu manuscripts
  • EdO :

Metadata of the Edition

  • Title: The Svayambhu. Digital Critical Edition and Translation of an Old Javanese Juridical Text
  • Text Identifier: DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu
  • Edited by Arlo Griffiths & Timothy Lubin
  • Copyright © 2019-2025 by Arlo Griffiths & Timothy Lubin.

This project has received funding from the European Research Council (ERC) under the European Union’s Horizon 2020 research and innovation programme (grant agreement no 809994).

Lubin’s work has been supported by fellowships from the National Endowment for the Humanities (USA) and the American Council of Learned Societies.

invocation

L:1K:1vM:1vavighnam astu.

1.

Account of Dharma

1.

vyavahārān didr̥kṣus tu brāhmaṇaiḥ saha pārthivaḥ | mantrajñair mantribhiś caiva vinītaḥ praviśet sabhām ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.001

1.1

kunaṅ ulaha saṅ prabhu, uniṅānira taṅ vyavahāranikaṅ rāt, arovaṅa ta sira brāhmaṇa vihikan(1) maṅaji, lavan mantri vruh(2) maviveka(3), sulakṣaṇaä ta sira tumamaä riṅ sabhā.

Translation

When the king is going to try a case, he should enter the court modestly accompanied by Brahmins and counselors who are experts in policy Now should his Majesty undertake to attend to litigation/affairs of this world, let him take as companions Brahmins who are knowledgeable and study Scripture, and likewise ministers with the wisdom to judge with discernment; with good conduct, he should enter the council.

2.

tatrāsīnaḥ sthito vāpi pāṇim udyamya dakṣiṇam | vinītaveṣābharaṇaḥ paśyet kāryāṇi kāryiṇām ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.002

2.1

aliṅgihāpagəha(4) ta sira riṅ sabhā, taṅanira təṅən atah ulahakənira, hayvātuduh-tuduh*(5) kiva(6), bhūṣaṇa-pahyasniṅ vvaṅ suśīlātah(7) lviranira, iṅət-iṅətənirātah yogyāyogyani(8) kāryanikaṅ mavyavahāra kalih.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

3.

pratyahaṁ deśadr̥ṣṭaiś ca śāstradr̥ṣṭaiś ca hetubhiḥ | aṣṭādaśasu mārgeṣu nibaddhāni pr̥thak pr̥thak ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.003

3.1

*sari masiha(9) sirān ṅiṅət-iṅəta makasādhanaṅ(10) varah-varah(11) saṅ hyaṅ āgama mānavādi(12), mvaṅ sakinapagəhaknikaṅ sapañjiṅ(13) deśanya, deśa ṅaranya,(14) sakaḍaṅayan(15), sajasun-(16)vuṅkal, savuravan(17), sakanuruhan, an(18) hana *kaparəkanya deniṅ āgama, ya ika(19) deśadr̥ṣṭa ṅaranya, an tan(20) deśa sasiki svadeśanikaṅ mavyavahāra(21), aṣṭādaśasu mārgeṣu(22), irikā sthānaniṅ vyavahāra vvalu(23) vlas kvehnya, salviraniṅ vicāraniṅ(24) vyavahāra, hana tinəmunya ṅkāna salah siki, paḍa madudva-dudvan(25) viṣayanya.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

4.

hiṁsāṁ yaḥ kurute kaś cid deyaṁ vā na prayacchati | sthāne te dve vivādasya bhinno ’ṣṭādaśadhā punaḥ ||
Parallels
  • This stanza is absent from Olivelle 2005’s constituted text, though it is referenced in his app. crit. for one manuscript. The stanza occurs in ed. Mandlik 1886 8.4 with reading bhinno, where the Svayambhu implies bhinne.

4.1

hiṁsāṁ yaḥ(26) kurute kaś cit, hana vvaṅ mamatyani nirdoṣa, kunaṅ(27) deyam vā(28) na prayacchati(29), tan paveh irikaṅ yogya vehakəna(30), aveh irikaṅ tan yogya vehakənanya kunaṅ, sthāne(31) te dve vivādasya(32), ya ika(33) sthānaniṅ vyavahāra, rvaṅ siki mūlanya(34), bhinne(35) ’ṣṭādaśadhā(36) punaḥ, matəmahan ta ya vvalu vlas vəkasan.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

5.

teṣām ādyam r̥ṇādānaṁ nikṣepo ’svāmivikrayaḥ | saṁbhūya ca samutthānaṁ dattasyānapakarma ca ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.004

vetanasyaiva cādānaṁ(37) saṁvidaś ca vyatikramaḥ | krayavikrayānuśayo vivādaḥ svāmipālayoḥ ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.005

sīmāvivādadharmaś ca pāruṣye daṇḍavācike | steyaṁ ca sāhasaṁ caiva strīsaṁgrahaṇam eva ca ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.006

strīpuṁdharmo vibhāgaś ca dyūtam āhvaya(38) eva ca | padāny aṣṭādaśaitāni vyavahārasthitāv iha(39) ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.007

5.1

lvirnya, teṣām ādyam(40) r̥ṇādānam(41), tan kasahuraniṅ hutaṅ(42), ādiniṅ vyavahāra. nikṣepa, tan kavehaniṅ patuvava(43). asvāmi(44)vikraya(45), adval tan dravya. sambhūya ca(46) samutthānam(47), tan kaduman ulihiṅ kinabehan. dattasyānapakarma(48) ca, *karuddhāniṅ(49) huvus vinehakən.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

5.2

vetanasya(51)na cadānam(52)(50), tan kavehaniṅ(53) upahan. samvidaś ca vyatikramaḥ, advā riṅ samaya. krayavikrayānuśayo(54), alarāmbəknyān(55) padvalnya,(56) paməlinya kunaṅ. vivādaḥ svāmipālayoḥ(57), vivādaniṅ(58) *pinaṅvanakən mvaṅ maṅvan.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

5.3

sīmāvivādadharmaś ca, kaücapaniṅ vatəs. pāruṣye daṇḍavācike, ḍaṇḍaniṅ sāhasa(59), vākpāruṣya. steyam(60), pavr̥ttiniṅ maliṅ. sāhasam, ulah sāhasa. strīsaṁgrahaṇam eva ca(61), ulah tan yogya riṅ strī, strīpuṁdharmo, dharmaniṅ laki-strī.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

5.4

vibhāgaś(62) ca, kadumaniṅ dravya. dyūtam(63), totohan tan(64) prāṇi. āhvānam(65), totohan prāṇi. padāny(66) aṣṭādaśaitāni, nahan ta vvalu(67) vlas lvirnya. vyavahārasthitāni ha(68), byakta pinakasthānaniṅ(69) vyavahāra.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

6.

eṣu sthāneṣu bhūyiṣṭhaṁ vivādaṁ caratāṁ nr̥ṇām | dharmaṁ śāśvatam āśritya kuryāt kāryavinirṇayam ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.008

6.1

eṣu(70) sthāneṣu(71) bhūyiṣṭham(72), ikaṅ vyavahāra(73)sthāna vvalu(74) vlas, kapva hana katəmunya ṅkāna(75), kapagəhakəna(76) saṅ prabhu, yuktinikaṅ vyavahāranya, apan gavayakənanira pagəh i(77) kāryanikaṅ(78) yogya pagəhakənanira.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

7.

yadā svayaṁ na kuryāt tu nr̥patiḥ kāryadarśanam | tadā niyuñjyād vidvāṁsaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ kāryadarśane ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.009

7.1

kunaṅ saṅ prabhu hayva sira gumavayakən(79) ikaṅ kāryāmivakṣa(80) guṇadoṣa, akona ta sira ri(81) saṅ brāhmaṇa(82) vihikan maṅaji(83), kumavruhana yogyāyogya(84)nikaṅ vvaṅ mavyavahāra kalih.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

8.

aṣṭādaśapadābhijñaṁ prāḍvivāketi saṁjñitam | ānvīkṣikyāṁ ca kuśalaṁ śrutismr̥tiparāyaṇam ||
Parallels
  • This stanza is absent from the constituted text in Olivelle 2005, though it is referenced in his app. crit. for ms. Ox2 after 8.9. Mandlik (p. 877) and Jha include the stanza at the beginning of Medhātithi’s comment on 8.9; in his notes, Jha (v. 9, p. 490) cites citations of this verse in medieval scholastic works. In contrast with the cases in Div. XX and YY, van Naerssen (van Naerssen 1956) did not notice that the Old Javanese text here implies the presence of this stanza because the Sanskrit original is not quoted.

8.1

saṅ brāhmaṇa saṅ vruh riṅ aṣṭādaśavyavahāra,(85) sira ta(86) saṅ sinaṅguh prāgvivāka(87), saṅ vruh riṅ aji tarka, vruh(88) riṅ śruti(89) veda.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

9.

vivāde pr̥cchati praśnaṁ pratipraśnaṁ tathaiva ca | priyapūrvaṁ prāg vadati prāḍvivākas tataḥ smr̥taḥ ||
Parallels
  • Brh_1,1.69 This stanza is present neither in the constituted text of Olivelle 2005, nor in its app. crit., but is known to have occurred in the Br̥haspatismr̥ti, a text often cited by medieval Indian dharmaśāstra authors. The Old Javanese paraphrase suggests that its author knew the Sanskrit stanza with a reading vicāre for vivāde.

9.1

kunaṅ ikaṅ takvan iṅ(90) vicāra, gavayakəna rumuhun, sādhana saṅ prāgvivāka irikaṅ(91) mavyavahāra kalih, vivekanira ta sahurnya vəkasan, mataṅyan(92) prāgvivāka(93) pva ṅaranira.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

10.

so ’sya kāryāṇi saṁpaśyet sabhyair eva tribhir vr̥taḥ | sabhām eva praviśyāgryām āsīnaḥ sthita eva vā ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.010

10.1

aṅiṅət-iṅəta ta(94) saṅ prāgvivāka(95), i kāryanikaṅ(96) mavyavahāra kalih, arovaṅa ta(97) sira vvaṅ yogya riṅ sabhā(98) tigaṅ viji, tumamaä(99) ta sirāluṅguhāpagəha(100) riṅ sabhā.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

11.

yasmin deśe niṣīdanti viprā vedavidas trayaḥ | rājñaś ca prakr̥to vidvān brāhmaṇas tāṁ sabhāṁ viduḥ ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.011

11.1

saṅ brāhmaṇa tigaṅ siki(101), paḍa vruh maṅaji, hana brāhmaṇa(102) sasiki prajñān(103) vidagdha, vinidhi muṅgva riṅ deśa saṅ prabhu, ikaṅ deśa papupulanira, yeka deśa sabhā ṅaranya de saṅ paṇḍita(104).

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

12.

na sā sabhā yatra na santi vr̥ddhā vr̥ddhā na te ye na vadanti dharmam | nāsau dharmo yatra na satyam asti na tat satyaṁ yac chalenānuviddham ||
Parallels
  • NarSm mā. 3.17/NMS vya. 80
  • MDhŚ08.012 dharmo viddhas tv adharmeṇa sabhāṁ yatropatiṣṭhate | śalyaṁ cāsya na kr̥ntanti viddhās tatra sabhāsadaḥ ||

12.1

ikaṅ sabhā(105), yan tan hana saṅ vr̥ddhah tan sabhā ṅaranya, saṅ vr̥ddhah yan tan vruh iṅ(107) dharma, tan vr̥ddhah ṅaranira,(106) saṅ vruh iṅ(108) dharma yan tan agəgvana(109) kasatyan(110), tan dharma ṅaranikā, kunaṅ yan tan ginavayakən(111) ikaṅ dharma riṅ sabhā, sukət paṅəməh ṅaranikā sahaneṅ(112) sabhā, mapan(113) ikaṅ deśa kinahananiṅ dharma, tan kavoraniṅ(114) adharmi, yeka sabhā ṅaranya.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

13.

sabhā vā na praveṣṭavyā vaktavyaṁ vā samañjasam | abruvan vibruvan vāpi naro bhavati kilbiṣī ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.013

13.1

kunaṅ ikaṅ vvaṅ aṅujarakən prāya yukti, salah denya vəkasan, makveh ujarnya, vvaṅ katon doṣanya(115), ika(116) ta kabeh tan yogya tumamaä riṅ sabhā.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

14.

yatra dharmo hy adharmeṇa satyaṁ yatrānr̥tena ca | hanyate prekṣamāṇānāṁ hatās tatra sabhāsadaḥ ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.014

14.1

mataṅyan maṅkana, dharmanika saṅ uniṅa riṅ dharma, hilaṅ ika deniṅ adharma riṅ sabhā, kasatyanira(117) maṅkanātah hilaṅ ikā(118) deniṅ adva riṅ sabhā, yapvan alah juga dharma deniṅ adharma, alah juga satya deniṅ adva, paḍa hana(119) pva ya riṅ sabhā, patimbunaniṅ(120) kuṇapa ṅaraniṅ sabhā yan maṅkana.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

15.

dharma eva hato hanti dharmo rakṣati rakṣitaḥ | tasmād dharmo na hantavyo mā no dharmo hato ’vadhīt ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.015

15.1

kunaṅ yan iṅilaṅakən saṅ hyaṅ dharma, maləs juga sira maṅilaṅakən, yan rinakṣa saṅ hyaṅ dharma, maləs juga sira maṅrakṣa(121), mataṅyan(122) maṅkana, hayvāṅilaṅakən dharma, liṅniṅ vvaṅ, tan paṅilaṅakən pva kita(123) dharma, tan paṅilaṅakən sira iri ya, maṅkana(124) liṅ ....(125)

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

16.

16.1

atəhər pramāṇastava(126).

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

16.2

apan(127) tan hana ləviha sakeṅ dharma, sira pinakapramāṇaniṅ(128) loka, sira(129)(130) ta pinakasvarga saṅ magave(131) hayu, sira pinakakaləpasan saṅ paṇḍita, tan maṅkana ikaṅ vvaṅ adharma, tan hana gamāntyanya(132) maṅkanāta saṅka pisana tuvi.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

17.

17.1

mapan ikaṅ loka kabeh, dharma umagəhakən(133) ika, kinapagəhakən pva sira de saṅ(134) yatna, maləs sira magəhakən, apan tan pāpa ikaṅ(135) loka maṅkana(136), ikaṅ tan aṅilaṅakən dharma.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

18.

vr̥ṣo hi bhagavān dharmas tasya yaḥ kurute tv alam | vr̥ṣalaṁ taṁ vidur devās tasmād dharmaṁ na lopayet ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.016

18.1

mataṅyan(137) maṅkana, ləmbu rūpa bhaṭāra(138) dharma, hana pva vvaṅ(139) tan(140) agave dharma, yeka pāpa liṅniṅ deva, maṅkana pva ya, hayva kita maṅilaṅakən dharma.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

19.

eka eva suhr̥d dharmo nidhāne ’py anuyāti yaḥ | śarīreṇa samaṁ nāśaṁ sarvam anyad dhi gacchati ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.017

19.1

saṅ(141) tumut ri kālaniṅ pati(142) sira ta bhaṭāra dharma, mitra tan pakarva pva, parəṅ ilaṅ mvaṅ śarīra, mvaṅ dharma, kunaṅ ikaṅ dravya len sakerika, salah paran ika.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

20.

pādo ’dharmasya kartāraṁ pādaḥ sākṣiṇam r̥cchati | pādaḥ sabhāsadaḥ sarvān pādo rājānam r̥cchati ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.018

20.1

saṅ hyaṅ dharma saparapatan(143) tinəmuniṅ mavyavahāra yan satya, maṅkana ikaṅ sākṣi yan satya, anəmu saparapatanira(144) saṅ hyaṅ(145) dharma, maṅkana saṅ mavivakṣa kabeh, yan satya anəmu saparapatanira saṅ hyaṅ dharmātah, saṅ prabhu anəmu saparapatanirātah, agəṅ juga phalaniṅ kasatyan ginavayakən(146).

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

21.

rājā bhavaty anenās tu mucyante ca sabhāsadaḥ | eno gacchati kartāraṁ nindārho yatra nindyate ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.019

21.1

saṅ prabhu tan kahanan sira riṅ(147) pāpa, saṅ mavivakṣa kabeh luput sira riṅ pāpa, ikaṅ mavyavahāra salah pakṣanya juga təmpuhanya, nininda siṅ(148) saṅkananya, kahava tkeṅ(149) deśa kahananya.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

22.

jātimātropajīvī vā kāmaṁ syād brāhmaṇabruvaḥ | dharmapravaktā nr̥pater na tu śūdraḥ kathaṁ cana ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.020 Our text gives no paraphrase for the first stanza grouped in this section.

yasya śūdras tu kurute rājño dharmavivecanam | tasya sīdati tad rāṣṭraṁ paṅke gaur iva paśyataḥ ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.021

22.1

maṅkana saṅ prabhu, yan śūdra prāgvivākanira(150), kaḍatvanira durbala(151) kṣaya, kadi ləmbu kapətək riṅ(152) latək ajro.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

Parallels
  • The last sentence has a parallel in Bhīṣmaparva 124.19: kadi ləmbu kapətək iṅ latək.

23.

yad rāṣṭraṁ śūdrabhūyiṣṭhaṁ nāstikākrāntam advijam | vinaśyaty āśu tat kr̥tsnaṁ durbhikṣavyādhipīḍitam ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.022

23.1

ikaṅ rājya yan kakehaniṅ(153) śūdra, akveh vvaṅ(154) manayākən deva iriya, tan pabrāhmaṇa ikaṅ rājya maṅkana, śīghra hilaṅ deniṅ lapā(155) vyādhi bhaya kaḍatvanira.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

24.

Parallels
  • YDh1.360 BrhSm1.1.106 vyavahārān svayaṁ paśyet sabhyaiḥ parivr̥to ’nvaham || [YDh 1.360 = BṛhSm 1.1.106]

24.1

maṅkana pva ya, maṅutusa ta sirāmivakṣaä(156)*, vvaṅ vruh iṅ āgama, śīghra maṅucapa yan tinakvanan, saṅ makveh kavruhnira(157) śruti veda(158), paḍaməlakəna vataṅan pāt, ikaṅ vetan *pamivakṣana(159), sakveh saṅ umuṅguh(160) irika, sira ta(161) paḍa umiṅət-iṅəta sarasaniṅ vyavahāra.

25.

dharmāsanam adhiṣṭhāya saṁvītāṅgaḥ samāhitaḥ | praṇamya lokapālebhyaḥ kāryadarśanam ārabhet ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.023

25.1

maṅkanānakəna(162) sajiniṅ vataṅan, apuy riṅ payajñan(163), kumbha mesya bañu, halalaṅ, sarvavīja,(164) maṇik curiga muṅgva riṅ səṇḍi. tumama pva saṅ prāgvivāka(165) riṅ sabhā, mavəḍihana, asalimputa(166), maṅañjalia riṅ caturlokapāla, luməkasa ta sira maṅiṅət-iṅəta kāryanikaṅ mavyavahāra kalih.

27.

2.

Protection of Faithful Women

29.

bāladāyādikaṁ rikthaṁ tāvad rājānupālayet | yāvat sa syāt samāvr̥tto yāvad vātītaśaiśavaḥ ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.027

29.1

kunaṅ dravya kaliliraniṅ(190) rare uvuh-uvuh(191), kəmitən kəkəsana saṅ prabhu, ikaṅ dravya, yan apa(192) maṅkana, yāvat sa syāt(193) samāvr̥tto(194), yan huvus(195) maṅaji, yan(196) tapvan vənaṅ rumakṣa dravyanya, kunaṅ yan huvus(197) mulih sakiṅ(198) gurunya, vənaṅ rumakṣa dravyanya, vehakəna ikaṅ dravya iriya.

30.

vaśāputrāsu caivaṁ syād rakṣaṇaṁ niṣkulāsu ca | pativratāsu ca strīṣu vidhavāsv āturāsu ca ||

  • MDhŚ08.028

30.1

strī valva-valvan mānak rare(199) rakṣanən(200) ika de saṅ prabhu, strī valu(201) tan pabapebu(202), strī valu(203) vyādhi, *makapaṅguhan(204) satyanya riṅ jalunya, ika ta katiga rakṣanən de saṅ prabhu, sira aṅilaṅakəna yan hana vvaṅ avamāna(205) iriya, mataṅnyan(206) maṅkana, ikaṅ(207) kasatyan haneriya, pāvak bhaṭāra dharma katvaṅananira(208), kunaṅ yan satya ikaṅ(209) strī, hayva(210) saṅ prabhu parabyāpāra irikā kabeh.

31.

3.

32.

pranaṣṭasvāmikaṁ rikthaṁ rājā tryabdaṁ nidhāpayet | arvāk tryabdād dharet svāmī pareṇa nr̥patir haret ||

  • MDhŚ08.030

32.1

kunaṅ hikaṅ dr̥vya tan ana saṅ madr̥vya, kəkəsana de saṅ prabhu, ikaṅ dr̥vya maṅkana, tluṅ tahun lavasanya(215), yapvan tka(216) tikaṅ madr̥vya, haminta i sira vehakna hikaṅ dr̥vya de saṅ prabhu, yapvan alivat sakeṅ(217) tigaṅ tahun, alapən tikaṅ(218) dr̥vya de saṅ prabhu.

4.

Account of (Non-payment of) Debt

49.

adhamarṇārthasiddhyartham uttamarṇena coditaḥ | dāpayed dhanikasyārtham adhamarṇād vibhāvitam ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.047

49.1

kunaṅ ikaṅ vvaṅ mahutaṅ, tagihən kədvakna(270) denikaṅ(271) mapihutaṅ, śuddhānya hutaṅnya ri saṅ pradhana(272), prakāśaknanya tuvi, *uvusaniṅ(273) hutaṅnya.

50.

yair yair upāyair arthaṁ svaṁ prāpnuyād uttamarṇikaḥ | tair tair upāyaiḥ saṁgr̥hya dāpayed adhamarṇikam ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.048

50.1

kunaṅ hikaṅ mapihutaṅ, upāyanya kapva kāraṇaniṅ pihutaṅnyan mijila(274), tan vehən(275) maṅgəh atuṅgu, kāraṇanyan panahuranaṅ(276) hutaṅnya.

51.

dharmeṇa vyavahāreṇa chalenācaritena ca | prayuktaṁ sādhayed arthaṁ pañcamena balena ca ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.049

51.1

tagihən, asih-asihən(277), konən manahura, kapiṅro, taṅtaṅən mavyavahāra(278), kapiṅtiga, hadānā sisilihan, kapiṅpat, dānana tuṅgal,(279) maṅkana upāyaniṁ sumādhya pihutaṅnya(280) mijila, tan kavnaṅ pva ya ikaṅ mahutaṅ deniṅ upāya pat, lakvakna ta kapiṅlimaniṅ upāya, valātkāran, irən huluna.

52.

yaḥ svayaṁ sādhayed artham uttamarṇo ’dhamarṇikāt | na sa rājñābhiyoktavyaḥ svakaṁ saṁsādhayan dhanam ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.050

52.1

ikaṅ mapihutaṅ(281), sumādhya pihutaṅnya mijila, saṅkerikaṅ mahutaṅ, tatan uhutana(282) de saṅ prabhu, apan tumagihakən(283) māsnya ikā, tunānyāya gatinya, kunaṅ ikaṅ ahutaṅ, ulih anyāya gatinya.

53.

arthe ’pavyayamānaṁ tu karaṇena vibhāvitam | dāpayed dhanikasyārthaṁ daṇḍaleśaṁ ca śaktitaḥ ||

  • MDhŚ08.051

53.1

kunaṅ ikaṅ *anaṅguh mamuhaka ri(284) hutaṅnya, tan katon riṅ pañji(285) hikaṅ puhakaknanya(286), sahurənya hikaṅ hutaṅ sakesi(287) riṅ pañji(288) saṅ pradhana(289), ḍaṇḍa ta ya mātra sakavnaṅnya.

54.

r̥ṇe deye pratijñāte pañcakaṁ śatam arhati | apahnave tu dviguṇaṁ tan manor anuśāsanam ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.139 This stanza is found in Olivelle 2005’s constituted text not after stanza 51 but only as stanza 139. See Olivelle’s comment on p. 956.

54.1

ikaṅ hutaṅ sinamayakən sahurənya denikaṅ ahutaṅ, ri tka samaya(290) pva tan sinahuranya, yogya ḍaṇḍan ikaṅ vvaṅ maṅkana, ḍaṇḍa pañcaśata(291) paṇa, tumutana(292) satus paṇa, mā, 10, mā, 2(293), yan samaṅkana hutaṅniṅ mithyanya(294), kunaṅ yan paṅas(295) tan pasamayānahura liṅnya, katəpətan(296) deniṅ sākṣi mvaṅ tulis, ləpihakna hikaṅ pañcaśata(297) paṇa, ku, 2, su, 3, mā, 2(298), riṅ satus *paṅḍaṇḍeriya, maṅkana śāsana(299) bhaṭāra manu.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

54*.

54*.1

ya tapva ahutaṅ, pinet kinuṅkuṅ ta ya de pradhana, sajatyahirahiri, məməndət kunaṅ, tan ambava Utənaradi, lvaṅ pivakaṅ nadya niṣṭa, pradhana tan sama ḍaṇḍa, ləbur pirak pradhana, təhər huculana kaṅ ahutaṅ.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

54*.2

salviriṅ niṣṭa tiniban hastacapala vākpāruṣya, tan katut(301) iṅ ubhaya, ləbur pirak kaṅ(302) pradhana, bantən iṅ pitara, ṅa.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

54*.3

mvah jajaka, hinuṅgah iṅ(303) rabiniṅ voṅ, makādy oraraṅaniṅ len, yathā(304) pinisah voṅ jalir ṅaran, jajaka pinikṣeṅ lokika, kneṅ lokika:sipat, ya ta lvir, 40000, tuvi pinaten kavnaṅ, ndah tan kneṅ lokika:, sajatya nir sipat.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

54*.4

voṅ apadva sinambat, hana len, tinurunakna śinabda, de upatya, sakvehiṅ sinambat buron hatavan brana, tinampak rah de haburva vnaṅ.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

54*.5

kunəṅ pvekaṅ tan tinuron, ḍaṇḍa kaṅ sinambat vrat iṅ apadu.

(300)

55.

apahnave ’dhamarṇasya dehīty uktasya saṁsadi | abhiyoktā diśed deśaṁ karaṇaṁ vānyad uddiśet ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.052

55.1

kunaṅ yan paṅas tikaṅ ahutaṅ, tuduhakna deśa kahanan yan pahutaṅ, pintonana(305) pañji mvaṅ sākṣi.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

56.

yatra na syāt kr̥taṁ pattraṁ karaṇaṁ ca na vidyate | na copalambhaḥ pūrvoktas tatra daivī kriyā bhavet ||
Parallels
  • Olivelle’s ms. La1 interpolates this stanza after 8.52; Mandlik records it in brackets after 8.51 (likewise KSS and Dave). Medhātithi cites it in his commentary on 8.51 as an illustrative quotation with the words “thus they say” (tathāhuḥ), and with the reading pūrvokto daivī tatra.

56.1

yan tan ana patranikaṅ anagih, sādhananiṅ hanagih(306) tan anātah, tan ana putra *kalāntara, tan anāmituturi, samāsatyaha juga ya, bhaṭāra kumavruha(307) dva-tuhunya.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

57.

adeśaṁ yaś ca diśati nirdiśyāpahnute ca yaḥ | yaś cādharottarān arthān vigītān nāvabudhyate ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.053

57.1

hanāpihutaṅ tumuduh ikaṅ deśa, pisaniṅuna deśanikaṅ mahutaṅ, hana ta deśa tinuduh pūrvaka, vkasan kinasnya, hana ta vruh kveh-kḍikniṅ pihutaṅnya(308), --> mvaṅ(309) tan vruh paknaniṅ piraknyan *hinutaṅ.

60.

  • MDhŚ08.056

60.1

liṅ saṅ prāgvivāka, huvus(313) tinakvanan(314) mami, lavanta mavyavahāra(315), adya siṅgih karika ujarnya ri kami(316), mavaraha ta kita iri kami, maṅkanā liṅ saṅ(317) prāgvivāka tatan sahur, hana tan eṅət ri(318) hujarnya tambayan(319), hana tatan vruh ri(320) rumuhun kāri(321), ika ta(322) maṅkana kabeh, yatika(323) sorakna vicāranya.

61.

jñātāraḥ santi mety uktvā diśety ukto diśen na yaḥ | dharmasthaḥ kāraṇair etair hīnaṁ tam iti nirdiśet ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.057
  • The third lemma suggest a difference transmission of the base text: diśety ukto diśen na cet.

61.1

jñātāraḥ(324) santi mety uktvā(325), hana ta(326) vvaṅ makveh sākṣinya, diśeti(327), kinon ta ya mijilakna sākṣinya, na cet(328), tatan vijilakən ya, ika taṅ maṅkana, varahakna yan sor pakṣanya(329), makanimitta salahniṅ kira-kiranya, dharma saṅ(330) prāgvivāka yan maṅkana.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

62.

abhiyoktā na ced brūyād vadhyo daṇḍyaś ca dharmataḥ | na cet tripakṣāt prabrūyād dharmaṁ prati parājitaḥ ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.058
  • The paraphrase suggests that the received reading, instead of vadhyo, was bādhyo, baddhyo or bandhyo, the former two being among the variant readings recorded by Olivelle. The paraphrase also seems to presuppose a reading trisākṣiṇam bruyāt (or the like) instead of tripakṣāt prabruyāt. But no such variant is reported in Olivelle’s edition.

62.1

hana vvaṅ managih-nagih, tinakvanan(331) kāraṇaniṅ pihutaṅnya(332), tatan sumahur kāpit(333), sikəpən(334) yogya daṇḍan ikā, satinagihnya(335) ləpihakna. kunaṅ ikaṅ anagih tan pahujarakna(336), trisākṣi, ndya(337) lvirnya, sākṣi, likhita, bhukti, yogya sorakna vicāranya, de saṅ prāgvivāka.

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

63.

yo yāvan nihnuvītārthaṁ mithyā yāvati vā vadet | tau nr̥peṇa hy adharmajñau dāpyau taddviguṇaṁ damam ||

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

ātmaiva hy ātmanaḥ sākṣī gatir ātmā tathātmanaḥ | māvamaṁsthāḥ svam ātmānaṁ nr̥ṇāṁ sākṣiṇam uttamam ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.084

87.

ekam evādvitīyaṁ tu yat satyenāvabudhyate | satyaṁ svargasya sopānaṁ pārāvārasya naur iva ||
Parallels
  • We tentatively restore the stanza in this way from the Old Javanese gloss and from the third stanza interpolated after 8.82 recorded in Olivelle’s edition for his witnesses TMd4 GMd1 MTr4 MTr6 Tr1 [Jolly Gr] Mandlik [ṭa] KSS Dave. Olivelle represents the interpolated stanza as follows ekam evādvitīyaṁ tad yaṁ martyo nāvabudhyate | satyaṁ svargasya saṁyānaṁ pārāvārasya naur iva ||, but records a variant ekam evādvitīye tu tan matvaivāvabudhyate from TMd4.

87.1

tan pakarva pva saṅka satyan(456) vruh ikaṅ loka, inaran ikaṅ satyena(457), hapan kasatya-vacananya haṇḍa mariṅ(458) svarga(459), kadi prahuniṅ vvaṅ mahyun məntasa.(460)

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

88.

nasti satyāt paro dharmo nānr̥tāt pātakaṁ param | sthitiś ca loke dharmaś ca tasmāt satyaṁ viśiṣyate ||
Parallels
  • This is the second of to two stanzas interpolated after 8.82 recorded in Olivelle’s edition, found in his witnesses GMd1 TMd4 Tr1 MTr4 MTr6 [Jolly Gr] Mandlik [ṭa] KSS Dave.

88.1

apan tan ana dharma lena sakeṅ kasatyan, iya dharma, iya satya, tan ana pāpa(461) len(462) sakeṅ(463) hadva, iya pāpa, iya hadva, saṅhāra(464) ṅaranika kalih, mataṅyan ta pagəh ikaṅ loka(465), dharma hetunikā, hayo(466) hiṅilaṅakən saṅ hyaṅ dharma de(467) saṅ mahyun məntasa.

89.

manyante vai pāpakr̥to na kaś cit paśyatīti naḥ | tāṁś ca devāḥ prapaśyanti svaś caivāntarapūruṣaḥ ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.085

89.1

118.

121.

dharaṇāni daśa jñeyaḥ śatamānas tu rājataḥ | catuḥsuvarṇiko niṣko vijñeyas tu pramāṇataḥ || r̥ṇe deye pratijñāte pañcakaṁ śatam arhati | apahnave taddviguṇaṁ tan manor anuśāsanam ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.137 MDhŚ08.139
  • It seems that our author’s copy of MDhŚ may have lacked 139abc, with 139d immediately following 137d. Stanza 138 will be paraphrased below. A long interpolation in L that cites stanza 139 in full along with an unidentified stanza complicates the evaluation of the text-critical situation.

121.1

ikaṅ sapuluh tahil kuna(676), ma, su, 2(677), mā(678), 8, vratnya pirak, sadharaṇa ṅaranya, kunaṅ ikaṅ pirak paṇa sapuluh(680) ma,(679) su, 2(681), mā, 8, tkanya(682), śatamāna ṅaranya(683), kunaṅ ikaṅ pataṅ tahil ma, su, 1, təkanya pirak, saniṣka(684) ṅaranya, kavruhana hīṅan bhaṭāra manu mavarah-varah(685).

130.

131.

ajaḍaś ced apogaṇḍo viṣaye cāsya bhujyate | bhagnaṁ tad vyavahāreṇa bhoktā tad dravyam arhati ||

  • MDhŚ08.148

131.1

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

132.

ādhiḥ sīmā bāladhanaṁ nikṣepopanidhiḥ striyaḥ | rājasvaṁ śrotriyasvaṁ ca na bhogena praṇaśyati ||
yaḥ svāminānanujñātam ādhiṁ bhūṅkte ’vicakṣaṇaḥ | tenārdhavr̥ddhir moktavyā tasya bhogasya niṣkr̥tiḥ ||
Parallels
  • MDhŚ08.149-08.150 Our author seems to have known the first Sanskrit stanza with the reading ādhisīmā. It is unclear whether he knew the second at all — whether the phrases after tan ilaṅa ya still concern the first stanza, whether they are a loose rendering of stanza 150 as we know it, or whether they correspond to a radically different version of that stanza. The use of a lowest-level instead of final punctuation after tan ilaṅa ya in all three manuscripts suggests that the scribes regarded what follows as part of the preceding paraphrase.

132.1

ādhisīmā, sīmā sinaṇḍakən, dravyaniṅ(792) rare uvuh-uvuh tinuvavakən, matuvava tan pasākṣī, matuvava sinākṣyakən, dravyaniṅ(793) brāhmaṇa tinuvavakən(794), dravyaniṅ ratu(795) tinuvavakən, ika ta kabeh, tan ilaṅa ya(796), yadyapin(797) kabhuktiha tuvi, katka riṁ ka:daṣavarsa(798), maṅəlyanana kaṅ amukti(799).

Translation

No translation available yet for this part of the edition DHARMA_CritEdSvayambhu

  • MDhŚ08.151

135.

  • MDhŚ08.153 Several manuscripts cited in the critical edition have kārikā (the form cited here by our author) rather than kāritā, the reading adopted by Olivelle.

135.1

144.

  • MDhŚ08.161

144.1

ikaṅ pradhana, mahyun ri(911) kavijilaniṅ pihutaṅnya(912), ikaṅ mahutaṅ kinavruhan(913) yan(914) ulih anyāya(915)nulihanya vkasan, ikaṅ maṅakū mati ya, sādhanaha(916), konkonakna(917) ya(918) sahurən(919).

om. LM (eye-skip)sakaḍaṅayan conj.
sadaṅayan LKM
None of the witnesses transmit the syllable ka that we conjecture on the basis of epigraphic evidence, especially the Sima Anglayang charter (14r1): sapinasukniṁ yavadvĭpa kabeḥ, lasun·, paḍa, paṅkaja, kanuruhan·, lamajaṁ, panumbaṁṅan·, pavuyahan·, deśa luvuk·, vuravan·, kaḍaṅayan· kabeḥ.sajasun-M
sajamus- LKsavuravanLK
savagavan ManLK
ndan Mika norm.
hika: LKtika Man tanM
hankan LKmavyavahāra conj.
vyava:hara Lvya:vahara Kvyavahara M
The conjecture seems necessary because svadeśa normally figures in possessive constructions with nouns indicating categories of people. Note that the same omission of prefix (m)a- is observed in §26, §159.aṣṭādaśasu mārgeṣu em.
Aṣṭadaṣasu margge Lhaṣṭa:deṣa:su ma:rgge Kastadasasu marge MvvaluL
valu Kriṁ valu Msalviraniṅ vicāraniṅLM
salviriṅ Kpaḍa madudva-dudvanL
padudvadudvan Kpada padudvan-dudvan M
This stanza is absent from Olivelle 2005’s constituted text, though it is referenced in his app. crit. for one manuscript. The stanza occurs in ed. Mandlik 1886 8.4 with reading bhinno, where the Svayambhu implies bhinne.hiṁsāṁ yaḥ em.
Iṅsīya LIṅsa:ya KMnirdoṣa, kunaṅLM
nirdoṣa:, maṅlarani nirdoṣa, kunaṁ K
It is possible that the absence of the phrase maṅlarani nirdoṣa in L and M results from eyeskip. But as long as we do not understand how the three manuscripts relate to each other, it seems more likely that K reflects an elaboration that captures two possible understandings of hiṁsāṁ kurute.vā norm.

Ahvanam· LKM
The vulgate reading of MānDhŚ is āhvaya here, but several mss. used by Ed share the reading with n that seems to have been received on Bali.padāny em.
pada Lom. Kbadam Mvvalu norm.
va:lu Lvalu KMvyavahārasthitāni haLKM
The vulgate reading of MānDhŚ is vyavahārasthitāv iha here, but it seems that the text received on Bali had the reading that we adopt here. Olivelle’s ms. Be1 has the variant -sthitāni ca.pinakasthānaniṅLM

yogya- LK
Cf. §2 iṅət-iṅətənirātah yogyāyogyani kāryanikaṅ mavyavahāra kalih.
This stanza is absent from the constituted text in Olivelle 2005, though it is referenced in his app. crit. for ms. Ox2 after 8.9. Mandlik (p. 877) and Jha include the stanza at the beginning of Medhātithi’s comment on 8.9; in his notes, Jha (v. 9, p. 490) cites citations of this verse in medieval scholastic works. In contrast with the cases in Div. XX and YY, van Naerssen (van Naerssen 1956) did not notice that the Old Javanese text here implies the presence of this stanza because the Sanskrit original is not quoted.saṅ brāhmaṇa saṅ vruh riṅ aṣṭādaśavyavahāra,LM
om. Ksira taLK
siranata MprāgvivākaLK
pragivaka Mtarka, vruhM
tarkkavruha Ltankavruha K
Note the absence of punctuation coupled with the use of an irrealis form in LK.śrutiLK
smvati M
This stanza is present neither in the constituted text of Olivelle 2005, nor in its app. crit., but is known to have occurred in the Br̥haspatismr̥ti, a text often cited by medieval Indian dharmaśāstra authors. The Old Javanese paraphrase suggests that its author knew the Sanskrit stanza with a reading vicāre for vivāde.takvan iṅ em.
tantraniṁ LKtankvaniṅ (taṅgvaniṅ?) M
Questioning is the topic of the stanza, which explains why a prāḍvivāka/prāgvivāka is so-named. Retaining the word takvan here from the slightly corrupt reading of M, we reject the readings matakvan (L) and patakvan (K) in the next sentence. Our author uses takvan again at the beginning of div 28.irikaṅM
matakvan irikaṁ Lpatakvan ikaṁ Kmataṅyan norm.
mataṅhyan LKmataṅya ta MprāgvivākaLK
pragivaka M
aṅiṅət-iṅəta taLM
haṅiṅətiṅəttha KprāgvivākaLK
pragivaka Mi kāryanikaṅL
hinaryyanikaṁ Kiṁ karyanikaṁ MtaKM
om. LsabhāLM
sana: KtumamaäM
jumamaha: LKsirāluṅguhāpagəha norm.
sira:luṅguḥhapagəha Lsiraluṅguḥhapagəha Ksiraluṅguhapagəha M
It would also be possible to interpet the manuscript evidence as supporting sirāluṅguh apagəha, with irrealis suffix only on the second form.

om. KmaṅkanaKM
maṅka L....
All mss. have atəhər (spelled at:hər) directly following liṅ. This seems grammatically impossible, as maṅkana liṅ is always used in a possessive construction immediately followed by a designation of the speaker. We can only guess that words like bhaṭāra manu have been omitted.pramāṇastava em.
praṇama:stava Lpr̥ṇattama:stava: Kpranatomastava M

tuhaL
tva K, titisniṅ rahnyaL
... Kprabhu, kumavruhana ta dva-tuhunikaṅ em.
prabhu kumavruhaniratadva:tuhunikaṁ Lprabhu, kumavruhanira:tanḍya:tuhunikaṁ K
Our emendation involves replacement of the syllables nira with na. Much depends here on whether or not to punctuate the text after prabhu, and whether to read maṅkana ta or maṅkanāta in the preceding clause. An alternative would be not to punctuate, to read maṅkana ta, and to emend kumavruhana ri kadvā-tuhunikaṅ.vāhyaliṅgādiL
vvahyaliṅga:ḍḍi K

kədvaknaM
kḍva:kna LKdenikaṅLK
dekaṅ Mpradhana norm.
pra:ḍa:na Lpr̥daṇa Kpradana M
OJED records only pr̥dana (one occurrence each in Koravāśrama and Kuṭāra-Mānava), but the source of this word is evidently Sanskrit pradhana, and sources not used by Zoetmulder support our choice to rely here on the spelling found in .*uvusaniṅLM

Our emendation is supported by Kuṭāra-Mānava §7 kaṅ amateni amanahurana hutaṅe kaṅ den-pateni ikā and §77 anake amanahurana hutaṅe kaṅ apəpəgatan ikā.

Neither of the two widely divergent readings for this passage yields a clear sense. The emendation presumes that ṅma in L is a copying error for 3.śāsanaK
śaṇasa Lya tapva ahutaṅ, …, ḍaṇḍa kaṅ sinambat vrat iṅ apadu.L
These paragraphs are absent in K and seem extraneous to our text.katut em.

yadṭa L
pintonana em.
mintonana LK
Olivelle’s ms. La1 interpolates this stanza after 8.52; Mandlik records it in brackets after 8.51 (likewise KSS and Dave). Medhātithi cites it in his commentary on 8.51 as an illustrative quotation with the words “thus they say” (tathāhuḥ), and with the reading pūrvokto daivī tatra.hanagih em.

ceta Lcetaḥ Kyan sor pakṣanyaL
yan pakṣanya subscr. sor KsaṅL
... K
The paraphrase suggests that the received reading, instead of vadhyo, was bādhyo, baddhyo or bandhyo, the former two being among the variant readings recorded by Olivelle. The paraphrase also seems to presuppose a reading trisākṣiṇam bruyāt (or the like) instead of tripakṣāt prabruyāt. But no such variant is reported in Olivelle’s edition.tinakvananL
tinakvana: KpihutaṅnyaL

The two words supplied here are assumed to have been omitted in transmission due to eye-skip. Their restoration is supported by two other occurrences of the pair atuha/rare in our text, in §XX and §YY.tuṅga-tuṅgalL

The conjecture we offer here is no more than a stopgap which, though inspired by the reading of K, has the great disadvantage of entirely obscuring the reading vika:ra in L. Other suggestions: yan avicāra śūdra? yan vicārī śūdra?sākṣinyaL

rika:Irikaṁ Lhika:, Ika:ṁ Kvicāra kalihK
vicaranya:, kaliḥ L-ta kabeh … kalih.L
om. K
Here begins a passage where the respective readings of our two witnesses are hard to reconcile with each other and with the underlying Sanskrit text as we know it. Our editorial choices are quite speculative.
ya vacananta, … brahmā. only in K
There is nothing at all in L corresponding to the Sanskrit stanza, while K seems to give here a paraphrase that only corresponds to the second half of the stanza. It can hardly be a coincidence that we find, a few paragraphs down (dyad 91), and then in both manuscripts, a paraphrase of the first hemistich of the Sanskrit stanza.kīrti em.
om. L (line omission)-kitta: KdenK
... L
Emend de?
hana pva … pinakasākṣi. only in K
There is nothing at all in L corresponding to the paraphrase found in K.mr̥ṣa, ya conj.
om. L (line omission)ya mr̥śa Kpañjanmanya norm.

om. L (line omission)majar K

om. L (line omission)sḍaṁnya: K
ulah yukti vr̥ddhi deniṅ kasatyanya,L

pavyavahara: L
We tentatively restore the stanza in this way from the Old Javanese gloss and from the third stanza interpolated after 8.82 recorded in Olivelle’s edition for his witnesses TMd4 GMd1 MTr4 MTr6 Tr1 [Jolly Gr] Mandlik [ṭa] KSS Dave. Olivelle represents the interpolated stanza as follows ekam evādvitīyaṁ tad yaṁ martyo nāvabudhyate | satyaṁ svargasya saṁyānaṁ pārāvārasya naur iva ||, but records a variant ekam evādvitīye tu tan matvaivāvabudhyate from TMd4.saṅka satyanL

dḍera L

ahala Kry akuL
yyaku KkaharəpnyaK
kaR̥p·nya LhiriyaK
riya Ltan vruh pva em.
tan· pva Ltan vruḥ pa Ktakvanən conj.
takvan LK
We cannot make sense of the text as it is transmitted, with takvan, as we require a passive verb form. There are rather numerous occurrences of takvanana in our text and in others, while takvanən is scarcely attested anywhere, but we favor this emendation as it seems easier to understand how the error takvan ikaṅ might have arisen from takvanən ikaṅ than from takvanana ikaṅ. A further complication lies in the fact that the sequence takvan ikaṅ is attested also in div 28.ikaṅ ulahK
ika hulaḥ LvinuniL
vanuni KiriyaL
iya: Kndya lvirniraK
om. L

paḍaṇḍa LKmandanda MirikaṅLK
ikaṁ Mḍaṇḍa saṅ prabhu … amaṅgih pāpa thus formulated in KM

The L reading is smoother with regard to the placement of the placement of saṅ prabhu; we have nevertheless decided to adopt the word order and punctuation of KM. The somewhat awkward placement of saṅ prabhu could be smoothened by moving the punctuation mark to stand before instead of after saṅ prabhu.duryaśaL

ṅaranya, [... K (eye-skip)samāṣa em.
sama:s· LMmāṣa conj.
mas· ṅaranya LM
We conjecturally remove ṅaranya from the text and emend transmitted mas· to māṣa.kunaM
kunaṁ L
This is the first occurrence of the expression tahil kuna whose second word is quite consistently transmitted as kunaṁ (though it incidentally figures as kuna here in M right before the word ṅaranya); apparently the meaning of the term had become obscure already by the time of the archetype of our manuscripts.

mapan yan MtāmraLK
tvaratamra M
It seems that our author’s copy of MDhŚ may have lacked 139abc, with 139d immediately following 137d. Stanza 138 will be paraphrased below. A long interpolation in L that cites stanza 139 in full along with an unidentified stanza complicates the evaluation of the text-critical situation.kuna em.
kunaṁ LKM2LK
ṅa Mmā em.
ma:s· LKMkunaṅ ikaṅ … sapuluh ma thus formulated in KM
kunaṁ Ikaṁ pirak ṣapuluḥ pana:, ma:, || ○ ||

R̥ṇadeve vratijñante, pañcama siṁtam ahartti, hapanave dadviguṇiṁ, tan manom anuṣasaniṁ,
ka, riṅ mavutaṁ yan masaṅketa:, yapva ta mityeṁ vuhus riṁ purvvaka:, ḍaṇḍanika:de bhūpatya, pañca satapa1×ṇa, kunaṁṅ apuvara haṅasiḥ dvigunotama ḍaṇḍa || ○ ||

nipṭiṁ vak nityaṁ* krodaṣṭaṁ*, valat śobr̥ṁ* namasṭadḍi, niṣṭe maḍyamaṁ* hutamaṁ*, purvvakaṁ* mituva ḍaṇḍaṁ*,
ka, hana ta ya:vaṁṅ apihutaṁ, tinagiḥ pihutaṁnya, tan paveḥ vetan drəvenya, hasr̥ṁ saṁṅ apihutaṁ, maṅalap sadr̥venya, maṅalap histri, sunu, bhūmi, nūn pasu sakalviriṁ patik vənaṁ yata hinalap·, vetniṁ kaṁniṣṭa vinaṅūn mityeṁṅ ūjar,, maka:don hinira:-hira:, haṅiṅindəti, haṅlindihi, tan druḥ kaṁṅ adr̥ve vaṁṅ apihutaṁ, lumka:s kaṅśa:seṁ tan hambava cihna Utər· daL̥m, hikya ṅaran valat sahaṣa havalat śobra, hiṅar:vakən vinalik rantas vitya:, mvaṁ tinibakna ḍaṇḍa mahirantaṁn kaṁ sa:hasobradḍi, kunəṁ pinaraṅgvakna vutaṁ, lavan daṇḍanekaṁ sahaṣa, vnaṅ pasaṅana vrat niṣṭa maḍyotama, ye niṣṭa vit hutaṁ mvaḥ paṅamet· sinahaṣa:, niṣṭa:ḍaṇḍa,, 5000, yen madya paṅamete, ḍaṇḍa, 10000, hutama paṅamete, ḍaṇḍa, 20000, sapaṅamete haṅsula:kna riṁ kaṁṅ avutaṅ, vaṣana, ḍaṇḍa riṁ saṁ bhūpatya || 0 || kunaṁ Ikaṁ pratekaniṁ harta:, sapaṇna:, 20, limaṁ paṇa:, 2, ku, tkeṁ hartha, kunaṁ ikaṁ pirak pana sapuluḥ, ma:, L
Manuscript L inserts a substantial interpolation between two iterations of the lemma. The interpolation notably contains the full text of MDhŚ 8.139 and an unidentified Sanskrit stanza. Although having stanza 8.139, with paraphrase, in this general part of the text is potentially attractive, the fact that the stanza is quoted in full is suspect, and the precise locus where it is inserted interrupts the paraphrase of 8.137. On these grounds, we favor the hypothesis that the segment of text found only in this witness is extraneous to our text.pirak paṇa sapuluhLK
sapuluh pana pirak M2LK
ṅa MtkanyaKM
om. Lśatamāna ṅaranyaM
satapana:, ṅa Lsatama:ṅaranya Ksaniṣka em.
saniskara LKMmavarah-varahKM
mavaraḥ L
limaṅL
lima KMpaṇa, paṇaLK
paṇa MtāmraKM
hamra Lmā,
om. LKM
In order for the arithmetic in this paragraph to work, we absolutely need this sentence to state a quantity of twelve and a half māṣas (i.e., 12 māṣa + 2 kupaṅ). Should we also supply ma before mā? Probably not, as ku in the last sentence is also not preceded by ma. For our author, ma, su seems to have been a fixed combination with ma no longer able freely to be combined with other units, as happens in the epigraphic corpus.2LK
ṅa Myan iṅ pirakM
pira:k· Lyani pirak· Kma, su, 1, … sevu paṇa, only in LKtkanyaK
om. LM2LK
lpa tkanyaK
om. Ltəkaniṁ təkanya Mmapan ikaṅLM
om. Lku, 1
1, ku Ltkanya riṅ pirak.K
yen pirak· || Ltəkanya riṁ pirak. iti pana-carita kunaṁ. M
Since it is not matched in LK, we reject the interesting chapter colophon inserted here in M.
pavarahLK
varaḥ MvasiṣṭhaLK
visista MgavayaknaLM
kavayakna KsatusLK
satis Mmāṣa em.
ma:s· LKMpradhanāṅalāntaraknaM
praḍana:, ṅalantarakna Lpr̥daṇa:kalantarakna Kku, 1,
ku, LKksa M
All witnesses omit the number 1 that is required after unit ku.tkaniṅ kalāntaraniṅK
tkaniṁ ṅalaṅanta:raniṁ Ltəkaniṅ aṅalantaraniṁ Mma, su, 9LM
ma:, 1, 9 K6, riṅ sapuluh tahun conj.
A riṁ salek· LKA, riṁ salek· M
The witnesses clearly point to a value of 9 suvarṇas. This means the total number of māṣas in question is at least 144, i.e., a factor of 10 times the annual yield on the loan. For this reason, we conjecture that the number corruptly transmitted as A in all witnesses was a 6, reject the reading riṅ salek despite unanimous manuscript support for it, and conjecture sapuluh tahun. It is not evident why our author would have thought of a ten-year period in the present context, but it may be relevant that this duration will be mentioned explicitly two time not far below (div 130, 132).
mā 2 em.
maṅu LKMaṅalantarakənL

vehin Lvehan KMalah ikaKM
halahi Ika Lamnaṅ iṅM
hamna Ikaṁṅ LAmnaṁ hikaṁ K
Our author seems to have known the first Sanskrit stanza with the reading ādhisīmā. It is unclear whether he knew the second at all — whether the phrases after tan ilaṅa ya still concern the first stanza, whether they are a loose rendering of stanza 150 as we know it, or whether they correspond to a radically different version of that stanza. The use of a lowest-level instead of final punctuation after tan ilaṅa ya in all three manuscripts suggests that the scribes regarded what follows as part of the preceding paraphrase.dravyaniṅLK
drəvya si MdravyaniṅL
dravya saṁ KMtinuvavakənM
hinuvava:kən· Ltinvavakən· Kniṅ ratuL
saṁ prabu KM (lexical)yaKM

riṁ Kya em.
yan LKM
We emend because kaməna is never construed with yan, while kaməna + ya + irrealis verb form is found, e.g., in the Patitihan charter (5r4–5) tigaṁ vṅi kamnā ya L̥L̥ba.dhānya norm.

Our emendation is inspired by such parallels as TK 52.25 (goh uttama deniṅ pəhanya mvaṅ ghr̥tanya) and Tk 1.69a (gr̥ta pə̄han sinaṅguh pavitra).pataraṇaL

OJED records only the spelling paṭāraṇa, but the spelling with ta found in our witness is actually very widespread.vāhya em.

mma:s· Lma:s· K
Several manuscripts cited in the critical edition have kārikā (the form cited here by our author) rather than kāritā, the reading adopted by Olivelle.gnəpanaL
gnəpana:Uga Kpradhanāṅalap kalāntara conj.
pradana:ṅalantara:kalap· Lpr̥daṇa:ṅalantara kalap· K
Since the sentence seems to us incapable of interpretation with the words aṅalāntara kālap that both witnesses transmit here, we are forced to resort to conjecturing that an inversion of word order has occurred, induced by the fact that aṅalap and aṅalāntara have their first two syllables in common.hanaL
hana ta K

ṅaran· LinalapanL
inalapn MyaM
ye Lkinalāntaran konkonanLM
The witnesses agree on a reading that seems corrupt. We are unsure how to emend. Among options we have considered are kalāntara-n kinonkon, kalāntara-n kinonakən, ikaṅ hutaṅ kinalāntaraniṅ konkonkan, kalāntaraniṅ konkonkan.denikaṅ em.

Both reading are equally acceptable. We tentatively prefer that with vvaṅ on the grounds of the unanimous manuscript support for ikaṅ vvaṅ mahutaṅ in div 49.pinintonakənyaLK
pinintonakəna MmeṅətaLK
meṅəta-meṅəta MriLM
riṁ K
iṅgataniṅLK
aṅgataniṅ Malaṅ-alaṅLK
aṅalaṅ-alaṅi Mśeṣaniṅ tukon … anak putuniṅ ahutaṅ thus formulated in L
śeṣaniṁ ḍaṇḍa, śeṣa vlan·, Ika ta kabeḥ, yan matikaṁ mahutaṁ, tan yogya tagihən hanaknya Ksesa vəlyan, ika ta kabeḥ yan mati kaṁ mahutaṁ, tan yogya tagihən anaknya Msesaniṁ, sesa vəlyan, ika ta kabeḥ yan mati kaṁ mahutaṁ, tan yogya tagihən anaknya Mśeṣaniṅ daṇḍa, śeṣa vlyan, ika ta kabeh, yan matīkaṅ mahutaṅ, tan yogya tagihən hanaknya KM
Paradosis of KM: śeṣaniṅ daṇḍa, śeṣa vlyan, ika ta kabeh, yan matīkaṅ mahutaṅ, tan yogya tagihən hanaknya
The two alternative ways of reading the last sentence, represented respectively by L and KM, seem equally acceptable. It is remarkable that where L reads śeṣaniṅ tukon, KM seem to reflect śeṣa vlyan in their hyparchetype, while they agree with L on reading śeṣaniṅ ḍaṇḍa. There is external textual evidence in Perpusnas L882 (mvah hutaṅ tan kaliliranā deniṅ putra, hutaṅ tan paputra, hutaṅ totohan, śeṣadaṇḍa, hutaṅ tukon, hutaṅ sajə̄ṅ) that might support conjecturing śeṣa ḍaṇḍa in our text. There is also evidence that tukon and vəlyan were felt to be equivalent in this genre of literature UBL Or 5037 (ana vvaṅ istrī linamar saptapayu sinrahan ikaṅ tukon mati taṅ istrīkaṅ sinrahan tukon vəlyan ika si baṅavan ika tan vaṅsulakna ikaṅ tukon).

cara:- LKM
The appearance of the word sabhā in the sentence supports our conjecture. The similarity of the akṣaras sa to ca and bha to ra seems to underlie an error shared here by all mss.paṅidəpakəna ləḥ sabhā sakeṅ sunya ika

No Sanskrit stanza has been identified as corresponding to the following prose.tinarimaLM
vinarima: Kparva-rvan em.

See the extensive dittography in the next section, where the reiterated readings of this passage confirm our emendation.sopāṅśuḥKM

ṅa L
No Sanskrit stanza has been identified as corresponding to the following prose.dravya … ri parva-rvanM
riṁ par:var:va:, sopaṅguḥ Ahuni, Avdi kavruhanya, tan kinavruhan· lvir18-12nya, hapan kinuṅkus·, Ikaṁ patuvava maṅkana:, Upanindi, ṅa || subscr. dr̥vya:kalilirra:n tinu18-13vavakən· ri par:var:van· L (dittography)riṁ parvarvan·, sapaṅśuḥ, Avani, Avḍi kavruhana:, Avibhavanivya, tan kina§◯vruhan lvirnya, hapan vinuṅkus·, Ikaṁ patuvava maṅkana:, Upaninḍi ṅaranya | druvye kaliliran tinuvavakə23r3n· riṁ parvarvan· K (dittography)
An ancestor of and has skipped back from ri parva-rvan to the same words in the preceding section, leading to wholesale repetition of an extensive passage.avibhāvyaḥLM
Avibavya KinalapM
Inalapa LIvnalapa Kri parva-rvanLM
riṁ rvarvan· KupanidhiM
Upadini LUpadiniṁ K
kunaṅ […] sākṣinya
The readings of both witnesses cannot be reconciled with each other without doing violence to the one or the other. It is noticeable that the reading of K is much more coherent than that of L. By the principle of lectio difficilior potior, L’s’ readings should probably be preferred: they are less consistent, somewhat elliptical, and compressed, whereas K’s readings look like an expansion and systematization. QUOTE K VERBATIM?kunaṅ […] kunaṅ sakaton sakarəṅə̄ denta(499) sākṣi, yen tuhu, śīghra
For the paraphrase of the second hemistisch of the Sanskrit stanza, see dyad 83.kunaṅ […] 2.
The second half of the Sanskrit stanza it not glossed at all. It is likely that corresponding sentences of the Old Javanese text have been lost due to eye-skip.ikaṅ […] yān
All witnesses read a lowest-level punctuation sign here and after the gloss of the next stanza: it seems that MDhŚ08.154–156 were considered to form a group.ikaikaṁ […] nikaṅ inakuniṅ bapanya panahuranya
This paragraph is transmitted ibn exceedingly corrupt form in all witnesses; we are forced to take recourse to extreme conjectures to obtain a coherent text.loka, sira…loka maṅkana
An omission due to eye-skip intervenes in Kṅaranya, limaṅ…ṅaranya, ikaṅ
An omission due to eye-skip intervenes in Kliṅ saṅ paṇḍita.…kālavr̥ddhi kārikāvr̥ddhi
An omission intervenes in Mpradhana…satuməkanaṅ kalāntaraniṅ
An omission intervenes in K

Apparatus


^1. vihikan] LK, vikanM
^2. mantri vruh] K, mantri riṁ vruḥL, mantrinira vruḥM
^3. maviveka] LM, mavikveka:K
^4. aliṅgihāpagəha] norm., haliṅgihapagəhaLM, haliṅgiḥ pagəha:K
^5. hayvātuduh-tuduh*] L, hayva tuduḥtuduḥKM
^6. kiva] LK, kitaM
^7. suśīlātah] KM, sugiḥla:taḥL
^8. yogyāyogyani] LM, hogya:yogyaniṁK
^9. masiha] LK, masitaM
^10. makasādhanaṅ] norm., makasa:danaṁLM, makasḍanaṁK
^11. varah-varah] KM, varavaraḥL
^12. mānavādi] K, manava:vīL, navaviM
^13. sapañjiṅ] LK, saṁ mañjiṁM
^14. deśa ṅaranya,] K, om.LM (eye-skip)
^15. sakaḍaṅayan] conj., sadaṅayanLKM • None of the witnesses transmit the syllable ka that we conjecture on the basis of epigraphic evidence, especially the Sima Anglayang charter (14r1): sapinasukniṁ yavadvĭpa kabeḥ, lasun·, paḍa, paṅkaja, kanuruhan·, lamajaṁ, panumbaṁṅan·, pavuyahan·, deśa luvuk·, vuravan·, kaḍaṅayan· kabeḥ.
^16. sajasun-] M, sajamus-LK
^17. savuravan] LK, savagavanM
^18. an] LK, ndanM
^19. ika] norm., hika:LK, tikaM
^20. an tan] M, hankanLK
^21. mavyavahāra] conj., vyava:haraL, vya:vaharaK, vyavaharaM • The conjecture seems necessary because svadeśa normally figures in possessive constructions with nouns indicating categories of people. Note that the same omission of prefix (m)a- is observed in §26, §159.
^22. aṣṭādaśasu mārgeṣu] em., Aṣṭadaṣasu marggeL, haṣṭa:deṣa:su ma:rggeK, astadasasu margeM
^23. vvalu] L, valuK, riṁ valuM
^24. salviraniṅ vicāraniṅ] LM, salviriṅK
^25. paḍa madudva-dudvan] L, padudvadudvanK, pada padudvan-dudvanM
^26. hiṁsāṁ yaḥ] em., IṅsīyaL, Iṅsa:yaKM
^27. nirdoṣa, kunaṅ] LM, nirdoṣa:, maṅlarani nirdoṣa, kunaṁK • It is possible that the absence of the phrase maṅlarani nirdoṣa in L and M results from eyeskip. But as long as we do not understand how the three manuscripts relate to each other, it seems more likely that K reflects an elaboration that captures two possible understandings of hiṁsāṁ kurute.

^29. prayacchati] em., prayaścatiLK, prayasatiM
^30. vehakəna] LM, vehiknaK

^42. kasahuraniṅ hutaṅ] conj., kasahurapihutaṁL, kasahurapyutaṁK, kasuhuraniṁ pyutaṁM • Our conjecture is inspired by a passage in the TaKa p. 30: maṅkana kagavayaniṅ yajñadharma, mvaṅ kasahuraniṅ utaṅ.

^44. asvāmi] LK, astami-M

^89. śruti] LK, smvatiM
^90. takvan iṅ] em., tantraniṁLK, tankvaniṅ (taṅgvaniṅ?)M • Questioning is the topic of the stanza, which explains why a prāḍvivāka/prāgvivāka is so-named. Retaining the word takvan here from the slightly corrupt reading of M, we reject the readings matakvan (L) and patakvan (K) in the next sentence. Our author uses takvan again at the beginning of div 28.

^125. ....] • All mss. have atəhər (spelled at:hər) directly following liṅ. This seems grammatically impossible, as maṅkana liṅ is always used in a possessive construction immediately followed by a designation of the speaker. We can only guess that words like bhaṭāra manu have been omitted.

^261. prabhu, kumavruhana ta dva-tuhunikaṅ] em., prabhu kumavruhaniratadva:tuhunikaṁL, prabhu, kumavruhanira:tanḍya:tuhunikaṁK • Our emendation involves replacement of the syllables nira with na. Much depends here on whether or not to punctuate the text after prabhu, and whether to read maṅkana ta or maṅkanāta in the preceding clause. An alternative would be not to punctuate, to read maṅkana ta, and to emend kumavruhana ri kadvā-tuhunikaṅ.

^392. dvija sākṣya dvija] L, yan ḍvija mavyavahara, dvija sakṣyaniraK
^393. yan śūdra ikaṅ mavyavahāra] conj., yan vika:ra sudraL, yan sudr̥ mavyavaharaK • The conjecture we offer here is no more than a stopgap which, though inspired by the reading of K, has the great disadvantage of entirely obscuring the reading vika:ra in L. Other suggestions: yan avicāra śūdra? yan vicārī śūdra?
^394. sākṣinya] L, sakṣyanyaK
^395. caṇḍāla] Lpc, cacaṇḍalaLac, caṇḍala mavyavaharaK
^396. sākṣinya] L, sakṣyanyaK
^397. kunaṅ […] sākṣinya] The readings of both witnesses cannot be reconciled with each other without doing violence to the one or the other. It is noticeable that the reading of K is much more coherent than that of L. By the principle of lectio difficilior potior, L’s’ readings should probably be preferred: they are less consistent, somewhat elliptical, and compressed, whereas K’s readings look like an expansion and systematization. QUOTE K VERBATIM?

^443. -ta kabeh … kalih.] L, om.K • Here begins a passage where the respective readings of our two witnesses are hard to reconcile with each other and with the underlying Sanskrit text as we know it. Our editorial choices are quite speculative.
^444. ya vacananta, … brahmā.] only in K • There is nothing at all in L corresponding to the Sanskrit stanza, while K seems to give here a paraphrase that only corresponds to the second half of the stanza. It can hardly be a coincidence that we find, a few paragraphs down (dyad 91), and then in both manuscripts, a paraphrase of the first hemistich of the Sanskrit stanza.

^472. tan vruh pva] em., tan· pvaL, tan vruḥ paK
^473. takvanən] conj., takvanLK • We cannot make sense of the text as it is transmitted, with takvan, as we require a passive verb form. There are rather numerous occurrences of takvanana in our text and in others, while takvanən is scarcely attested anywhere, but we favor this emendation as it seems easier to understand how the error takvan ikaṅ might have arisen from takvanən ikaṅ than from takvanana ikaṅ. A further complication lies in the fact that the sequence takvan ikaṅ is attested also in div 28.

The somewhat awkward placement of saṅ prabhu could be smoothened by moving the punctuation mark to stand before instead of after saṅ prabhu.

^654. kuna] M, kunaṁL • This is the first occurrence of the expression tahil kuna whose second word is quite consistently transmitted as kunaṁ (though it incidentally figures as kuna here in M right before the word ṅaranya); apparently the meaning of the term had become obscure already by the time of the archetype of our manuscripts.

^678. mā] em., ma:s·LKM
^679. kunaṅ ikaṅ … sapuluh ma] Thus formulated in KM, kunaṁ Ikaṁ pirak ṣapuluḥ pana:, ma:, || ○ ||

R̥ṇadeve vratijñante, pañcama siṁtam ahartti, hapanave dadviguṇiṁ, tan manom anuṣasaniṁ,
ka, riṅ mavutaṁ yan masaṅketa:, yapva ta mityeṁ vuhus riṁ purvvaka:, ḍaṇḍanika:de bhūpatya, pañca satapa1×ṇa, kunaṁṅ apuvara haṅasiḥ dvigunotama ḍaṇḍa || ○ ||

nipṭiṁ vak nityaṁ* krodaṣṭaṁ*, valat śobr̥ṁ* namasṭadḍi, niṣṭe maḍyamaṁ* hutamaṁ*, purvvakaṁ* mituva ḍaṇḍaṁ*,
ka, hana ta ya:vaṁṅ apihutaṁ, tinagiḥ pihutaṁnya, tan paveḥ vetan drəvenya, hasr̥ṁ saṁṅ apihutaṁ, maṅalap sadr̥venya, maṅalap histri, sunu, bhūmi, nūn pasu sakalviriṁ patik vənaṁ yata hinalap·, vetniṁ kaṁniṣṭa vinaṅūn mityeṁṅ ūjar,, maka:don hinira:-hira:, haṅiṅindəti, haṅlindihi, tan druḥ kaṁṅ adr̥ve vaṁṅ apihutaṁ, lumka:s kaṅśa:seṁ tan hambava cihna Utər· daL̥m, hikya ṅaran valat sahaṣa havalat śobra, hiṅar:vakən vinalik rantas vitya:, mvaṁ tinibakna ḍaṇḍa mahirantaṁn kaṁ sa:hasobradḍi, kunəṁ pinaraṅgvakna vutaṁ, lavan daṇḍanekaṁ sahaṣa, vnaṅ pasaṅana vrat niṣṭa maḍyotama, ye niṣṭa vit hutaṁ mvaḥ paṅamet· sinahaṣa:, niṣṭa:ḍaṇḍa,, 5000, yen madya paṅamete, ḍaṇḍa, 10000, hutama paṅamete, ḍaṇḍa, 20000, sapaṅamete haṅsula:kna riṁ kaṁṅ avutaṅ, vaṣana, ḍaṇḍa riṁ saṁ bhūpatya || 0 || kunaṁ Ikaṁ pratekaniṁ harta:, sapaṇna:, 20, limaṁ paṇa:, 2, ku, tkeṁ hartha, kunaṁ ikaṁ pirak pana sapuluḥ, ma:,L • Manuscript L inserts a substantial interpolation between two iterations of the lemma. The interpolation notably contains the full text of MDhŚ 8.139 and an unidentified Sanskrit stanza. Although having stanza 8.139, with paraphrase, in this general part of the text is potentially attractive, the fact that the stanza is quoted in full is suspect, and the precise locus where it is inserted interrupts the paraphrase of 8.137. On these grounds, we favor the hypothesis that the segment of text found only in this witness is extraneous to our text.
^680. pirak paṇa sapuluh] LK, sapuluh pana pirakM
^681. 2] LK, ṅaM
^682. tkanya] KM, om.L
^683. śatamāna ṅaranya] M, satapana:, ṅaL, satama:ṅaranyaK
^684. saniṣka] em., saniskaraLKM
^685. mavarah-varah] KM, mavaraḥL
^686. limaṅ] L, limaKM
^687. paṇa, paṇa] LK, paṇaM
^688. tāmra] KM, hamraL
^689. mā,] , om.LKM • In order for the arithmetic in this paragraph to work, we absolutely need this sentence to state a quantity of twelve and a half māṣas (i.e., 12 māṣa + 2 kupaṅ). Should we also supply ma before mā? Probably not, as ku in the last sentence is also not preceded by ma. For our author, ma, su seems to have been a fixed combination with ma no longer able freely to be combined with other units, as happens in the epigraphic corpus.

^691. yan iṅ pirak] M, pira:k·L, yani pirak·K
^692. ma, su, 1, … sevu paṇa,] only in LK
^693. tkanya] K, om.LM
^694. 2] LK, lpa
^695. tkanya] K, om.L, təkaniṁ təkanyaM
^696. mapan ikaṅ] LM, om.L
^697. ku, 1] , 1, kuL
^698. tkanya riṅ pirak.] K, yen pirak· ||L, təkanya riṁ pirak. iti pana-carita kunaṁ.M • Since it is not matched in LK, we reject the interesting chapter colophon inserted here in M.

^700. vasiṣṭha] LK, visistaM

^704. pradhanāṅalāntarakna] M, praḍana:, ṅalantaraknaL, pr̥daṇa:kalantaraknaK
^705. ku, 1,] , ku,LK, ksaM • All witnesses omit the number 1 that is required after unit ku.
^706. tkaniṅ kalāntaraniṅ] K, tkaniṁ ṅalaṅanta:raniṁL, təkaniṅ aṅalantaraniṁM
^707. ma, su, 9] LM, ma:, 1, 9K
^708. 6, riṅ sapuluh tahun] conj., A riṁ salek·LK, A, riṁ salek·M • The witnesses clearly point to a value of 9 suvarṇas. This means the total number of māṣas in question is at least 144, i.e., a factor of 10 times the annual yield on the loan. For this reason, we conjecture that the number corruptly transmitted as A in all witnesses was a 6, reject the reading riṅ salek despite unanimous manuscript support for it, and conjecture sapuluh tahun. It is not evident why our author would have thought of a ten-year period in the present context, but it may be relevant that this duration will be mentioned explicitly two time not far below (div 130, 132).

^828. pradhanāṅalap kalāntara] conj., pradana:ṅalantara:kalap·L, pr̥daṇa:ṅalantara kalap·K • Since the sentence seems to us incapable of interpretation with the words aṅalāntara kālap that both witnesses transmit here, we are forced to resort to conjecturing that an inversion of word order has occurred, induced by the fact that aṅalap and aṅalāntara have their first two syllables in common.

^878. pinintonakənya] LK, pinintonakənaM
^879. meṅəta] LK, meṅəta-meṅətaM
^880. ri] LM, riṁK
^881. iṅgataniṅ] LK, aṅgataniṅM
^882. alaṅ-alaṅ] LK, aṅalaṅ-alaṅiM
^883. śeṣaniṅ tukon … anak putuniṅ ahutaṅ] Thus formulated in L, śeṣaniṁ ḍaṇḍa, śeṣa vlan·, Ika ta kabeḥ, yan matikaṁ mahutaṁ, tan yogya tagihən hanaknyaK, sesa vəlyan, ika ta kabeḥ yan mati kaṁ mahutaṁ, tan yogya tagihən anaknyaM, sesaniṁ, sesa vəlyan, ika ta kabeḥ yan mati kaṁ mahutaṁ, tan yogya tagihən anaknyaM, śeṣaniṅ daṇḍa, śeṣa vlyan, ika ta kabeh, yan matīkaṅ mahutaṅ, tan yogya tagihən hanaknyaKM • Paradosis of KM: śeṣaniṅ daṇḍa, śeṣa vlyan, ika ta kabeh, yan matīkaṅ mahutaṅ, tan yogya tagihən hanaknya • The two alternative ways of reading the last sentence, represented respectively by L and KM, seem equally acceptable. It is remarkable that where L reads śeṣaniṅ tukon, KM seem to reflect śeṣa vlyan in their hyparchetype, while they agree with L on reading śeṣaniṅ ḍaṇḍa. There is external textual evidence in Perpusnas L882 (mvah hutaṅ tan kaliliranā deniṅ putra, hutaṅ tan paputra, hutaṅ totohan, śeṣadaṇḍa, hutaṅ tukon, hutaṅ sajə̄ṅ) that might support conjecturing śeṣa ḍaṇḍa in our text. There is also evidence that tukon and vəlyan were felt to be equivalent in this genre of literature UBL Or 5037 (ana vvaṅ istrī linamar saptapayu sinrahan ikaṅ tukon mati taṅ istrīkaṅ sinrahan tukon vəlyan ika si baṅavan ika tan vaṅsulakna ikaṅ tukon).

^1058. tinarima] LM, vinarima:K
^1059. parva-rvan] em., r:var:va:L, parvarva:KM • See the extensive dittography in the next section, where the reiterated readings of this passage confirm our emendation.
^1060. sopāṅśuḥ] KM, somaṅguḥL
^1061. avuni] K, AhuniṁL, avaniM
^1062. avəḍi] LK, avə22v28daM
^1063. vinuṅkus] LM, vinuṅkas·K
^1064. upanidhi] M, UpanindiL, UpaninḍiK
^1065. ṅaranya] KM, ṅaL
^1066. dravya … ri parva-rvan] M, riṁ par:var:va:, sopaṅguḥ Ahuni, Avdi kavruhanya, tan kinavruhan· lvir18-12nya, hapan kinuṅkus·, Ikaṁ patuvava maṅkana:, Upanindi, ṅa || subscr. dr̥vya:kalilirra:n tinu18-13vavakən· ri par:var:van·L (dittography), riṁ parvarvan·, sapaṅśuḥ, Avani, Avḍi kavruhana:, Avibhavanivya, tan kina§◯vruhan lvirnya, hapan vinuṅkus·, Ikaṁ patuvava maṅkana:, Upaninḍi ṅaranya | druvye kaliliran tinuvavakə23r3n· riṁ parvarvan·K (dittography) • An ancestor of and has skipped back from ri parva-rvan to the same words in the preceding section, leading to wholesale repetition of an extensive passage.
^1067. avibhāvyaḥ] LM, AvibavyaK
^1068. inalap] M, InalapaL, IvnalapaK
^1069. ri parva-rvan] LM, riṁ rvarvan·K
^1070. upanidhi] M, UpadiniL, UpadiniṁK
